channel.title: Artefacts CheatSheet on Analyst
channel.description: Recent content in Artefacts CheatSheet on Analyst

item.title: 🤔 How do I check for remote connections?
item.description: Windows RDP Event Logs On source machine: Security🛡️ (4648) TerminalServices-RDPClient 🌸 (1024 and 1102) On the target machine: Security 🛡️ (4624, logon type 10, 4778 and 4779), see Session name to confirm it’s an RDP.

item.title: 🤔 How Do I Check For Logs Clearing?
item.description: Windows ❗️These techniques require admin or higher privileges. ❗️Common with ransomware When the Security trail is deleted, 1102 is usually created afterwards.

item.title: 🤔 How Do I Check For Malicious Autostarts?
item.description: Windows Tasks Event logs Two trails are of use are Microsoft-Windows-TaskScheduler/Operational 🍇 (disabled by default on the newer systems) and Security 🛡️.

item.title: 🤔 How Do I Check For Reconnaisance Activity?
item.description: Windows Event logs Monitoring for these events will cause a lot of noise and false positives.

item.title: 🤔 How do I check program execution?
item.description: Windows You can use Prefetch which is the most reliable source. However, if the program is NOT there, it doesn’t mean it wasn’t executed.

item.title: 🤔 How Do I Check System Information?
item.description: Windows Registry, of course. AmCache, Registry 🗄️ You can see firmware, hardware and OS info there.

item.title: 🤔 How Do I Find Malicious or Compromised Accounts?
item.description: Windows Event logs It starts with the event 4720 (account created) and multiple 4732 events (member added to some security-enabled group).

item.title: 🤔 How Do I investigate logon events?
item.description: Windows Event Logs There is a fine line between logon and account logon events, and that line is not just one word.

item.title: 🤔 How Do I Spot Bruteforcing Activity?
item.description: Windows Event logs There will be no shortage of 4625 events (unsuccessful login) showing up in the logs.

item.title: 🤔 How Do I Spot Injections?
item.description: Windows Sysmon logs, 25. References Expand… Something here
